currentDoc:
Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many pe

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Com

The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effectiv

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see t

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know

That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentio

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. By comparriso

 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. By c

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. By

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be arou

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that y

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a st

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been frien

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousand

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two spe

Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal.

Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cat

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there/

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would ta

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.

We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more o

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in

The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of th

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many case

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. A

Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Ani,al

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger.

 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibi

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of a

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely o

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to fee

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about it, it'

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about it, it's just the way that s

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about it, it's just the way that some of

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about it, it's just

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosi

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals o

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals over a person. At lea

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals over a person. At least the human has a ch

 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals over a person. At least the human has a chance to so ao

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals over a person. At least the human has a chance to so somethi

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals over a person. At least the human has a chance to so something about their situ

The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals over a person. At least the human has a chance to so something about their situation. The anima

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

In my opinion, it's perfectly fine to care more about an animal than a stranger. I feel the same way. There's a variety of reasons for this. The first is that animals are more defenseless so we tend to feel more protective of them, more similar to a baby. Basically we're wired to protect those who can't help themselves. That's just a natural response. A stranger who may be in danger is more likely to be able to save themselves than an animal. 
Secondly, I feel that identifying with animals is easier for me personally than other people.
 Many people feel this way. Animals can't talk so there is no chance of having some beliefs that conflict with one another. Communication is simple and effective. It works great for both parties involved. 
Another reason is that the animals genuinely love us and are so grateful for our help.
 We respond to that. With humans we don't always see that unless we personally know the human and their intentions. Meanwhile you can be around an animal for moments and feel a connection to it that you wouldn't feel around a stranger. 
Most importantly, animals can be our friends and grow with us.
 We've been friends with dogs for thousands of years. That shows the bond that can grow over time between two species. We're still working on that connection with other animals such as cats, but it will get there. And that bond is not possible with a stranger. That bond would take time to develop. 

So there's nothing wrong with focusing more on animal welfare in general. Animals can not take care of themselves in many cases and need our help. Animal charities are often overlooked. It's our responsibility to take care of animals as they rely on us. There's no reason to feel bad about choosing to help animals over a person. At least the human has a chance to so something about their situation. The animal does not.
